Target function code is:
```c
void OS_IdleLoop()
{
    /*
     * Wait until the shutdown value is set to the shutdown number
     * In most "real" embedded systems, this will never happen.
     * However it will happen in debugging situations (CTRL+C, etc).
     */
    while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        OS_IdleLoop_Impl();
    }
}
```

List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement.

explanation:
To determine whether OS_IdleLoop violates the MISRA rule about well-formed for-loops we must check whether the loop-control object(s) used in the loop condition are modified inside the loop body (including via called functions). Although the loop in OS_IdleLoop is a while, the MISRA restriction about not modifying loop-control objects inside the body (and that function calls in the body count toward body behavior) still requires the same information. The listed symbols are required for these reasons:

- OS_SharedGlobalVars (struct definition): We need the full struct definition to identify the GlobalState member and its type/attributes (e.g. volatile, atomic) so we can tell whether it is a loop-control object and how reads/writes behave.

- OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState (member declaration, type and qualifiers): The loop condition directly uses this member. Its type (signed/unsigned/integer/enum/boolean), volatility/atomic qualifiers, and scope determine whether modifications inside the loop body would violate the MISRA constraint.

- OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER (macro/constant definition and type): Knowing its type and definition ensures the comparison in the loop condition is a simple value compare and reveals any side-effects from the macro (if it were e.g. a function-like macro). Also needed to ensure the condition is not using an object that could be modified by the body.

- OS_IdleLoop_Impl (full implementation): This function is called in the loop body; MISRA requires that the behaviour of called functions be considered part of the loop body. We must inspect its code to see whether it (or any functions it calls) modifies GlobalState or any other object used in the loop condition.

- All functions called (directly or indirectly) by OS_IdleLoop_Impl (implementations): Transitive callees may modify GlobalState or other objects used in the condition. Their implementations are needed to determine side effects that would make the loop control object persistently modified by the loop body.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler (implementation/stub): The static call graph lists this as a callee of OS_IdleLoop. Even if not present in the small source excerpt, any test harness or instrumentation invoked from the idle loop must be examined for side effects on GlobalState.

- Any global variables written by OS_IdleLoop_Impl or its callees (declarations/definitions): If the body modifies other globals that are used in the loop condition (or that alias GlobalState), those must be known to judge compliance.

In short: we must be able to see the declarations and full implementations of the loop-condition objects and every function invoked from the loop body (including transitive callees and test stubs) to prove that no object used in the loop condition is modified by the body. Without those symbols/definitions the MISRA check cannot be completed.
